article_title: Conflicts of the Maghrawa and Zenata in Morocco

sections.subtitle: The Khazrunid Dynasty: A Branch of the Maghrawa

paragraphs.text: The Khazrunid dynasty, a Berber dynasty, held power in a portion of Morocco during the Middle Ages . They were a branch of the Maghrawa of Zenata, considered a major Moroccan tribe . The Khazrunids established their rule in Sijilmasa in 367 AH / 977 AD, governing in the name of the Spanish Umayyad Caliph Hisham II Al-Mu’ayyd .

Sijilmasa was a crucial hub for communication and commerce, connecting the Mediterranean, the Sahara, and the Orient . It was a pivotal city in the gold trade . The Khazrunids controlled Sijilmasa from 367 AH / 977 AD to 445 AH / 1053 AD, with interruptions due to temporary Fatimid and Zirid incursions .

During this period, almost all of Morocco was under Fatimid rule, yet the Spanish Umayyads minted coins in Sijilmasa . A revolt led by Ziri in Fas temporarily disrupted Khazrunid control around 388 AH / 999 AD . According to Ibn Khaldun, Wanudin became an independent ruler in Sijilmasa after 390 AH / 999 AD .
The Al-Moravids conquered Sefrou in 455 AH / 1063 AD, leading to the extermination of the Khazrunid family and their followers .

Ibn Khaldun's accounts are the primary source for Moroccan history, but they contain contradictions regarding the Khazrunids' reigns and lack details for the period . Numismatic evidence, specifically Khazrunid gold coins, provides valuable insights into the political dynamics of the time . The study of these coins helps to understand the conflicts between the Khazrunids and the Umayyad caliphate of Spain, and the Fatimids .

The Khazrunid dynasty had more than three rulers, as previously thought . Two additional rulers, Muhammad son of Mas'ud and Mas'ud son of Muhammad, are included in the new analysis based on Ibn Al-Khatib . This study corrects previous interpretations of Wanudin's reign and expansion, pointing out inaccuracies in existing numismatic studies . The scarcity of dated Khazrunid coins, issues with clipped margins, and the misreading of inscriptions (e.g., "Wazir"/"Wanudin") have posed challenges to previous numismatic studies .

New types of Khazrunid gold coins have been identified, and detailed descriptions of their inscriptions, often referring to Hisham II and Sulayman Al-Musta'in, have been provided . Previous errors in identifying the rulers who struck coins have been corrected, and new attributions have been suggested based on coin inscriptions . Numismatic evidence (coins) is used to refine and correct historical accounts of the Khazrunid period .
